normalised: What is the deal with Rental Yields in India? Is it worth buying that Mumbai flat to rent out?

unnormalised: **What's the deal with Rental Yields in India? Is it worth buying that Mumbai flat to rent out?**
normalised: Okay, so you are thinking of becoming a landlord, eh? Like, maybe buying that one B H K in Bandra, Mumbai, and renting it out? First things first: rental yield is your new best friend. It is basically the percentage of the property's price you are getting back annually in rent.

unnormalised: Okay, so you're thinking of becoming a landlord, eh? Like, maybe buying that 1 BHK in Bandra, Mumbai, and renting it out? First things first: rental yield is your new best friend. It’s basically the percentage of the property's price you're getting back *annually* in rent.
normalised: Think of it this way: If you buy a flat for rupee one crore and rent it out for rupee twenty five thousand per month (rupee three lakhs a year), your gross rental yield is three percent. Not exactly “Om Shanti Om” levels of success, is it?

unnormalised: Think of it this way: If you buy a flat for Rs. 1 Crore and rent it out for Rs. 25,000 per month (Rs. 3 Lakhs a year), your gross rental yield is 3%. Not exactly “Om Shanti Om” levels of success, is it?
normalised: Now, that is G R O S S. You gotta factor in property taxes (Mumbai's notoriously high!), maintenance (those leaky taps!), maybe even some void periods (when you do not have a tenant). That eats into your net yield.

unnormalised: Now, that's GROSS. You gotta factor in property taxes (Mumbai's notoriously high!), maintenance (those leaky taps!), maybe even some void periods (when you don't have a tenant). That eats into your net yield.
normalised: Generally, in India, rental yields tend to be lower than, say, fixed deposit rates. We are talking maybe two to four percent in many major cities.

unnormalised: Generally, in India, rental yields tend to be lower than, say, fixed deposit rates. We're talking maybe 2-4% in many major cities.
normalised: But, here is the catch: property appreciation. You are betting that the value of the flat will go up over time. Plus, it is a tangible asset, unlike, you know, Dogecoin.
